title: Very efficient
body: Contacted practice on Monday pm via eConsult. I was contacted Tuesday am and referred 2ww and provided with an appointment for following week in secondary care.  Many thanks to Dr Laura Power.    Tracy

title: Compassionate and caring
body: This GP practice just gets it right. Same day appointments, easy online booking system and easy to contact. Responsive and caring. I have been treated with respect and understanding over the last 6 years while going through multiple health issues and mental health crisises. This surgery has a welcoming reception and always seem to go the extra mile to help when I have been in need of assistance.

title: Caring and understanding
body:
Reception staff were very caring and accommodating to my needs. Went out of their way to help me.
Doctor was thorough but very reassuring.  Listened to my knowledge of my condition and how I felt. Very happy and feel looked after by the best! Hate the appointment system, if your illness makes it impossible to be on the phone by 8 am then you have no chance of seeing a dr.  Love the on line service as fairer and at least I get to speak to a dr if they think my needs warrant a call.  Feel safer knowing I can email and get a reply, rather than phoning and ‘computer says no’ Loving the new staff that speak to you rather than snarl if you ask for an appointment. Please change the telephone by 8am system, so difficult if you are disabled to be ready for finger on redial button race!  Would the old ticket system work?  If you really need to see a doctor then you will wait.  If you’re not desperate and the waiting number is higher than you want to wait, then you leave.  Worked a tread before.

title: Great Treatment and Superb Staff
body:
I was admitted to ASU on 29/7/2020, from the minute I stepped over the threshold I was cared for, and my best interests held as the first priority. My recovery was made quicker and easier sue to the sense of humour, empathy and expertise of the men and women of ASU, B5 and C6 wards. I cannot thank you all enough for the care I received, I am now able to return to work and resume my life thanks to the sheer hard work and determination of these amazing people. Special Mention goes out the IV Ninja of Ward B5 who changed two IV Lines without waking me up, BZ, good drills there!
All in all a superb environment focussed on excellence.
Thank you all from the bottom of my heart

title: Exemplary service and care
body: I visited Scarborough Hospital A&E on Sunday 2nd August 2020 am, following a cycling accident. I firstly spoke to Sainsburys Pharmacy and NHS 111 to be invited to attend A&E. I received excellent care, very thorough, kind and professional, following a head trauma. I received various tests including, blood, ECG and CT scan. I got the all clear approx 3 hours from my arrival at hospital. Thankyou for your kindness and efficiency, from all, reception, health care assistants, nurses and Doctors. Much appreciation for our wonderful NHS

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent care from Royal Eye Unit
body: I had cataract operations on both eyes. The care given by the consultant and team could not have been better. It was highly professional and the staff were very friendly. Everything I needed to know was explained very clearly. I am very grateful.

readBy.name: Kingston Hospital NHS Foundation Trust Diabetes Team

title: Excellent practice
body: I was in as a day care admission for a hernia op, the care l received from all staff from arriving and leaving could'nt have been better. Every thing that was happening was explained in detail. Cannot praise all staff enough.

readBy.name: Kettering General Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fantastic care
body: I attended Sandborne Suite for surgery. From the moment I arrived the lady on the main desk was kind and helpful.The nurses were amazing as was the aneathatist and Consultant. They all took time to ensure I was comfortable and understood what was happening. The excellent care continued when I was admitted on to ward 7 for 6 days. Thank you to all staff ☺️

readBy.name: The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: First class care
body: It was my second time in A&E in two weeks. I was rushed in on both occasions and so I can’t comment on the waiting room. All the staff were polite and very professional, they attended to my pain needs as soon as humanly possible. I was admitted to POU ward again! All the staff on the ward are absolutely fabulous. Kind, caring and attentive with a little bit of humour. I can’t praise Tameside hospital enough, absolute first class treatment. Thank you.

readBy.name: Tameside and Glossop Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: Scheduling appointments and exams.
body:
I have been trying to schedule a blood test for more than 3 weeks and I can't do it due to the unpreparedness of the staff.

I have been to the GP personally more than 5 times and the reception staff are extremely unprepared.

They always say that the Doctor will call you and he never does.

I got my blood test forwarded and to my surprise it was the wrong blood test.

I wasted my time and half a day to go to the hospital to collect the blood and the GP gave me the wrong referral.

This is about health, I need to do this blood test because I just finished a treatment for the disease and I need to know if I am cured or not to continue with the treatment.

Today I went to the GP personally, again to beg the right referral and once again they said that the doctor will call me.

This GP plays with the health of his patients. This is ridiculous.

I don't advise this GP to anyone, look for something better.

title: Thankyou ward 7b
body: Having  recently had a hip replacement my care by everyone i met was of the highest standard. I was treated with respect and the friendly staff and support teams were the best. Always had time for a chat even though they were busy. I would recommend Southmead without fail. I felt safe and protected on the Green Ward. Best wishes to you all.

author: Arob
title: Breastfeeding support
body:
My son is now 27 months old and has recently self weaned from breastfeeding. I wanted to say a big thank you to the groups that supported me in my breastfeeding journey. In the first few weeks I had help from Breastfeeding support workers who helped me correct my son’s latch after his tongue tie was cut. In my son’s first year I regularly attended Bosom Buddies and the Fife Breastfeeding Cafe (Milky Way). These groups provided support and information to help with any challenges I came up against. They also helped me to feel connected to other breastfeeding mums, who in turn introduced me to other breastfeeding friendly groups. After I returned to work and could no longer attend regularly in person, the facebook groups continued to be an excellent source of support, information and a feeling of community.  
I was determined to breastfeed from the start (despite tongue tie, reflux and multiple allergies) but I don’t think I would have had the confidence to continue feeding past 1 year without these groups.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

links.id: introduced me to a support network beyond group

title: Follow up service commendable
body: I would just like to post my review because of the follow up service I received yesterday. The surgery treat you as a person and not a number and therefore I have no hesitation to recommend this practice

title: Very caring
body: I was admitted with symptoms of a heart attack and I was very scared as have never experienced any heart problems before. The staff not only provided excellent clinical care but their care and concern was very helpful to me in coming to terms with a life changing event. Everyone - cleaners, porters, catering, nurses and doctors were friendly and kind and I cant thank them enough. If you need treatment in hospital I cant think of a better place to be.

readBy.name: Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Eternally Grateful
body: My son Darren was rushed to SGH from Guernsey for Heart surgery.  He is still there, but will hopefully fly back at the weekend.  They have been totally amazing, very supportive and extremely professional.  I cannot fault them in any way whatsoever.  They are all worth their weight in gold, the surgeon, everybody associated with pre and post heart surgery and care have been amazing.  I cannot thank them enough, I cannot use the appropriate words to describe how pleased I am with my sons care.  They are all angels sent from heaven, thatnk God for people like these, I wish I could be there to show my gratitude.  I am blown away by them, thank you God for giving us such wonderful people.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Great responsive service
body:
During the last couple of difficult months for healthcare providers, unfortunately for non Covid related reasons, my husband and I have needed to use the GP more than normal.  The team at Bridge Cottage have been excellent.  Whilst the e-consult form is VERY long, the response was prompt and helpful.  
Telephone appointments have been returned on time and for us have been as useful as a traditional face to face appointment.  When required having the video option also allowed me to easily show the GP symptoms.
Great job, thank you.  Please keep telephone appointment options this simple after this pandemic.

author: Tibbs
title: Visit to MEDDOC
body: I was given an appointment to come in and see an out of hours GP. When the doctor came he didn't introduce himself. He began to question me about the problem which is understandable. In the assessment he was palpating and asking questions and I said no pain there because you are barely palpating the affected area. So he continued assessing the leg and when it became painful he stopped. He tried to flex the said hip but it was painful so he stopped. Then he told me that I could get down from the bed. He did my obs then told me he's prescribing a stronger painkiller co-codamol and I should see my GP tomorrow if it persists. Said I should wait outside and he'll write and give me the prescription. This doctor didn't mention what he thought the problem could be. Pharmacies are closed on a Sunday and he didn't even give painkiller just to cover me for the night. That made me feel as though I had wasted my time going there and that he doesn't really know what he's doing so the best thing to do would be to get rid of me quickly and redirect me to my original GP 😔

author: Diesel Doris
title: Poor mental health service
body: Took my daughter four times to queen's hospital, only in the fourth visit and when she assaulted her family member and security, did they help us she was suffering from psychosis. The A& E staff nurse was very stern and unhelpful it took us ages to getting her in hospital and she allowed her to leave. Finally sectioned on fourth attempt for 72 hours care on ward was brilliant and mental health nurse was amazing. Mental health team came from Goodmayes and didn't want to admit her she is now in a mental health unit in Wales under section 2 not very impressed.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration
North East London NHS  Foundation Trust

author: mother in surrey praising Alison ENT  wycombe
title: Alison in ENT Wycome Hospital
body:
My adult daughter has a number of disabilites. Referred to Alison in ENT last year we were delighted with the care and expertise shown to my daughter who had been suffering with wax blocking both ear drums. Alison arranged two monthly visits and gradually was clearing my daughter's ears, taking account of the sensitivity felt by her.  
At the last visit in January, before lockdown one ear had been cleared and was again showing a little wax; the other ear showed 10% of the ear drum.  
Alison made our visits so calm, and was sensitive to my daughter's needs.  
Since January there have been no visits. One GP at my daughter's medical practice refuses to attend the residential home to check for wax as he says this is not an emergency. Another GP at the same practice, the one who arranged the ENT sessions, is willing for my daughter to be taken to the medical practice, making a special arrangement appointment, to check the ears but the residential home feel it is preferred that my daughter does not attend the surgery due to lockdown.  
My daughter does not show signs of distress so no infection is indicated but as she has no speech she cannot tell people, or sign, to say how much she can hear. She puts up with a lot of things without complaint. She showed no distress when both her ears were blocked with hard dark wax. She just didn't hear properly. Hearing is so important, and vitally so when she cannot verbalise.  
What is the answer here as lockdown looks to continue for some time?  
Normally I take her to any medical or dental appointment but I am not in a position presently to override the precautions in place to safeguard residents. At the same time I consider seven months without a look at her ears is unacceptable.  
  
[Unsure about 'Seeing the whole me']

title: Great care
body: The care received from in the endoscopy department from receptionist to discharge all the staff were fantastic. Thank you very much.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: eaglegm67
title: Caring, friendly and professional A&E Victoria Hospital Kirkcaldy
body:
At around 9:30 pm last night (2 August 2020), I was taken to the A&E at Victoria Hospital last night suffering high blood pressure.  
I wish I could do more than thank all the staff who cared for me, starting at a very polite and friendly receptionist to the caring and efficient triage nurse (Ms. Henderson) to Dr Calabria who handled my case. Dr Calabria was simply exceptional. Not only was she meticulous, but showed genuine care about my well-being. She explained the purpose of the tests in a simple clear language, and treated me with utmost respect and attention.  
This, like many other visits to hospitals, make me realise how luck we are to have people like you.  
Thank you very much.

title: Amazing Care
body:
A call back requested to discuss concerns over father’s health, consent given. 
The Doctor called back in time period stated. During a period when they are so overwhelmed, the doctor gave as much time required to listen, diagnose, and discuss concerns raised. This gave so much reassurance, not only to my father, but to the whole family for the care and support offered and received. 
Thank you

author: L66A
title: I was left in great pain without being assessed
body:
I was admitted to the ERI by ambulance one Friday in June at approx. 1700 . I was suffering from severe abdominal pain and regular vomiting caused by chronic pancreatitis . This was diagnosed in 2014 and I have had many similar flare ups over the past six years .  
Soon after I was admitted I was seen by a doctor in casualty who took details and offered me IV morphine to ease the pain. They also told me that the GI dept had been informed I was here and somebody from there would see me soon . I pointed out that I was taking 40mg MST every day and that giving me 10mg IV morphine might not help much , they replied that it was all that they could give me but I would get something stronger from GI staff once they had assessed me. The IV morphine didn't have any effect on the pain and I was given several further doses until I felt it was pointless taking any more because it was having no effect and that taking more morphine might restrict my chances of being given something stronger by a member of the GI staff. Every time a nurse administered the morphine they waited to see if it was working and when it hadn't, they all told me not to worry because someone from GI would see me soon and give me something to properly help me . I frequently told them that my pain was at an 8 to 9 out of 10.  
Around 2100 I was moved to the Acute Medical Unit , Base 2 and the last thing the nurse from A&E told me was that she hoped GI would see me soon and give me some pain relief at least. My pain was still between and 8 and 9 until it gradually subsided to an 8 out of ten about 0800 on the Saturday. By this point I had been in hospital for fifteen hours in agony but by then I was getting more and more distressed because nobody from GI had turned up to give me something to help me .  
It wasn't until 1015 that a GI specialist saw me in the ACU. I made sure I was up , dressed and had had something to eat before then because I was determined that I was leaving hospital soon by this point . I told him my pain was an 8 out of 10 but I hadn't been sick again . They told me that I could be discharged that day but said they would get someone to speak to me about my newly diagnosed diabetes of which I was unaware until my blood sugars were closely monitored the night before.  
By midday I was so fed up with the wait and asked the nurse on duty to remove the canula from my arm and return my supply of morphine MST tablets . I also explained that the reason I was desperate to leave was because I was upset about how long it had taken GI to see me . She asked me if I would wait for a discharge letter , which she stated wouldn't take long and I agreed because I didn't want it to look like I had not met my obligations as a patient by discharging myself , particularly when I was still in a great deal of pain .  
I was finally given my letter a little before 1800 on Saturday, 6 hours later . When I read the discharge letter it incorrectly states that I was given IV morphine which worked .  
I am writing to complain primarily about the time I was left in great pain in hospital without being assessed by somebody who was in a position to help me. I have always regarded a 10 out of ten on the pain scale to be pain so bad I pass out so to be at 9 or 8 for me is almost completely unbearable.  
In 2014 I first experienced similar pain and was admitted to ERI again by ambulance and had an almost identical 17 hours plus wait to be seen by a GI specialist. On that occasion I discharged myself because I was so frustrated at being left in hospital in pain and nobody who could help me did . I am not making the 2014 event a complaint but am including it as it provides vital context as to my reasons for not being admitted to hospital when my pain becomes unbearable and my daily MST tablets aren't enough to help.  
I also want to point out the emotional distress my recent experiences in hospital have caused me. During the 15 hours I spent in great physical pain almost two weeks ago , I began to get more and more frustrated and then upset that nobody who could help me was coming . This led me to thinking that I would be better off at home and that it was very unlikely I would ever come back to hospital, no matter how much pain I was in.  
The delay in me being discharged from AMU was also really frustrating , particularly since the staff knew that I was desperate to get home. I do acknowledge that an event happened around 1300 in Base 2 but that was dealt with within an hour. When I read the letter, I was very disturbed to read the false picture of my stay they portrayed and also how long it actually took him to write it. If they had checked with A&E surely they would have known the IV morphine wasn't working .The emotional distress took me several days to recover from . Today is the first day I have felt up to the task of reliving my experience in order to write to you

author: mental case paul
title: Mental health
body: I've had mental health issues for 40 years and every time I'm in crisis I get the same old thing put on a waiting list for months then nothing happens .. it feels like unless you have money there is absolutely no support for them who want to end there lives people are committing suicide every single day because they have been put on waiting list. when it comes to mental health Im sure that 99. 9% of us end our lives is at least partly because of the months of waiting to be seen its a complete joke

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: No information
body: My Father was admitted  to AAU last week. Since then he has been moved 4 times. He has dementia and is very confused.  He finally  landed up on Croxley ward. The staff on there are quite rude and dont give us any information  on my fathers condition.  That is when we eventually  get them to answer the phone. I must say AAU are brilliant  but once a patient  goes on to a ward the standard  of care seems to drop dramatically.  I appreciate  that you are busy but we had no contact  with my Dad  for 2 days. And the practice  of facetime,  which means we have to have Apple products is not fair to people  that have Android  phones

author: Suzzane
title: Masks
body: Every Monday we come to Medway hospital for my husband cancer treatment. The rest of the time we are in lockdown. I am distressed at the number of nursing staff with masks under their chin. We were a mask, despite we only go from home to hospital to home, to protect them. Why are they not protecting us? The care is very very good but not the risk some staff are putting us at.

title: Admin staff rude & biased
body:
My Blood/cervical scan tests results needed communicating to the IVF clinic (I have gone through this experience once with similar problems - my bloods needed to be taken 3times as each time someone forgot that one test that was needed). 
Having had a terrible experience in the past, I checked a dozen times with the clinic and confirmed with the nurse the process of the tests and I was told it would be sent directly to the clinic. As I was anxious, I checked if the tests had been sent as the IVF clinic were not proceeding with me despite my cycle. 
Over a month had passed and the admin staff kept telling me that the secretary will action sending the test results to the IVF Clinic, I even gave them the email which I was shocked they needed from me given they must have at some point communicated with them? When asked about a timeline they said they could'nt tell when the sect will action it. I kept telling them that I will miss my cycle and the test results are already out as on my repeated requests they have been sent to me, however they need an Agresso login which I don't have as I don't work for the NHS, neither could the Fertility clinic access them (whom I fwded the email). 
End result, no one took responsibility of sending the results, I missed the cycle and there is still no clarity on when the results will be sent (or ever they will). When I was upset over the phone I was told to keep my emotions over check when speaking to staff (as I said 'what the hell' is going on). When I asked about Diversity and Inclusiveness within the practice (non-clinical staff) I was told it was too confidential to disclose. When I asked to speak to a Practice Manager, I was told she will call me when she can but it cannot be today as it is not a priority (which I can understand given Covid but it would still be useful to know if it will happen this week or next month). Basically after a month of follow up, nothing has come out of it and I am told to keep my emotions under check as complaining to admin staff is not tolerated in the practice. So I have really no where to go and no one to go to and my entire life depends upon an admin staff's mood to send that one email. 
PS: Nurses and Drs in this practice are lovely and deserve the praise.

title: Unprofessional
body: I have never ever known such a unresponsive doctors in my life 3 days trying to ring for my elderly mum to respond to a request they made up to 17 times a day I have tried and been on hold for up to 20 minutes are there no professionals in this practice to answer the phone I can’t email what a debacle disgusting!!!!

title: very professional
body: everything done in a very professional manner. baring in mind the  corona virus restrictions the hygiene arrangements were excellent. i would like to thank you for a smooth and painless operation, and very much improved vision

author: Ms Bookworm
title: Recent CAU visit and follow-up care
body:
In early June, I began experiencing a dull, persistent ache/pain on my right side. It culminated one evening in being in intense stabbing pain and discomfort. I'd had my appendix removed in my teens, so knew it wasn't that. I was seen by my GP the next morning, who referred me to Ayr CAU. Long story short, after several hours in the team's excellent care, which included a CT scan, they concluded that it may have been a kidney stone, although nothing of that nature remained tin evidence on the scan. However, via this scan, they also spotted that my left ovary was enlarged and the doctor advised he would be referring me for a gynae appointment as well as a renal follow-up. I was incredibly grateful for their thoroughness and all-round care.  
This appointment came through really quickly and I was seen first by the excellent Michelle and her team. In fact, to say Michelle's manner and care was "excellent" really is an understatement. She gave generously of her time and experience to explain things to me and most of all, was so reassuring. Not in a glib "there, there, I'm sure it will be fine" way but really genuinely reassuring, explaining things properly, unhurriedly and not patronising or anything. All the team were caring too, making you feel at ease in a really uneasy environment.  
After this, I had an equally quick follow-up ultrasound to get a more detailed look than the CT scan could provide. The two ladies who saw me that day too were so kind and professional, keeping me relaxed and informed as they did the procedure.  
And this was followed up, once again, so quickly by an appoinment I had today with gynae consultant Dr Konamme. He was lovely - professional, considerate, explaining things well, and so thorough. I had another camera scope but while all this was happening, there was lots of light-hearted conversation amongst the supporting nursing staff, that kept the smile quota high and the anxiety level low, being a great deflection from what is understandably an uncomfortable procedure. Instead of feeling tensed up, I was as at ease as possible. And Dr Konamme took the time to show me the good news, pointing things out on the screen and reassuring me that, in his opinion, everything looked fine. My appointment concluded with the invitation to contact his secretary directly should another similar occurrence happen within the next 6 months.  
And just this evening, Michelle called just to check in and make sure I was ok and to see if I had any remaining questions etc. following today's appointment. And also to let me know not hesitate to get in touch should anything crop up in the near future that concerns me in this area.  
How do you even find language for this level and quality of care? From the GP appointment, and CAU visit, to the three visits to the gynae team, it has simply been a journey of true care, the utmost professionalism and just lovely, considerate human beings. And all this in the midst of a global pandemic! I'm truly beyond grateful to each and every one of them.  
And to the Whitehall government if you read these forums (and you really should!) - pay heed! Our NHS are not just world-class, but world-leading. Even under severe austerity cuts and challenges, we are the envy of the world.

title: Rude Receptionist
body: Wow, the doctors, nurses, secretaries here are all wonderful, polite and happy to assist, the receptionist though is a completely different story! I contacted the surgery with a pretty reasonable request (to which the hospital assisted me with in the end to save me any more stress) I was told I should not be bothering GP's with such requests when they are busy. I simply required proof of a diagnosis, this required the receptionist to press print on her screen. This one particular receptionist would not let me speak to a secretary or Doctor and I wasn't allowed an appointment either as I was wasting Dr's time.  All I can say is perhaps the partners here may want to consider employing people with customer service skills.  Found lots of reviews all saying the same thing!!!

title: dissapointed
body: I am shocked and disappointed, your receptionist who my family have known for a long time is leaving the surgery on Friday 7th august, how can you let this happen? they are the doctors, when this person is away it is so noticeable it will have a detrimental effect on the patients and the surgery in general, they have always done their job and much more, please avoid this happening .

title: fantastic prompt care
body: I sent an email at 2.30pm.  Was phoned by Dr at 3.50, and was seen at 4.20!  Now acting on the advice and feel very reassured.  Thank you so much.

author: nhsnurse2
title: Poor Post-operative care in Gynae ward
body:
Recently my mother underwent a laparascopic procedure, and her care in ward 208 (I believe a temporary home for ward 211) really fell short of what I expected from Aberdeen Royal Infirmary as we have in the past had much better experiences.  
I spoke to her in the evening after her surgery, and could hardly speak to her as she was vomiting. When I then spoke to the nurses I was told that she could not have any anti-sickness as "she had already had that in theatre".  
When I also asked the nurses about pain relief, as she said she was sore, I was told "sorry we can't give her anything for pain when she is being sick". I suggested perhaps an injection? and they said they would ask the doctor.  
Any time I phoned the ward, it was very difficult to get some-one to answer, and staff frequently wouldn't tell me how she was getting on, suggesting that I phoned her mobile phone and making it clear that the call was an inconvenience.  
She was discharged a few days later, however without any instructions about do's and don'ts etc, she was told that all the information leaflets had been packed away as the ward was moving back to where it normally was. Investigations before her operation indicated that she would need to be started on some new medication. She was given this without any instructions on how often or when to take this - it was not labelled either.  
Unfortunately only a few hours after discharge, I had to take her back to A&E with vomiting and fever. She could not self-refer to the ward as instructed, as they would not answer the phone, it rang and rang until it cut off. That night, despite assurances someone would call me, no one did, so after a couple of hours I called the ward, only to be told "there's nothing to tell you at the moment, why don't you just call in the morning". This was far from reassuring as I was really concerned about her.  
Following investigations, she was discharged 3 days later, still not able to eat or drink very much at all, and when we unpacked her tablets, the anti-sickness tablets had been missed out. Apparently the nurse had told her that if she wanted them she would have to wait for quite some time and this would delay her getting home. She was so keen to leave the ward, she just accepted this, which of course meant her GP had to arrange some later that day.  
I would say that she is still recovering very slowly, and both of us are now really apprehensive about any further admissions.  
However there were two staff who deserve a mention, as mum tells me they were very kind and their care was excellent. I think one of these nurses might have been the only person to actually update me on her progress once when I called, so I appreciate that.

title: Professionalism with a welcoming smile.
body: The staff and Doctor Alexandra were both totally professional and so welcoming especially in this particularly difficult time.I realise it is a cliché but that was some of the best medical customer care I have been fortunate enough to receive. Thank you.

title: The Eye department is excellent.
body:
The eye department could not have been more attentive and efficient, thank you. The department had far fewer patients and treatment was done quickly and each stage we efficient.

As someone who has to be in a wheelchair it was elsewhere in the hospital I had concerns. Walkways, lifts,  shops, enterance,  transport area.  People not following social distancing, not wearing masks, why is this not compulsorary? I felt very very  vulnerable. People are all nice and attentive but I didn't feel safe. I wore a mask and the correct gloves, I was concerned to protect others but now I wonder about my health over the next weeks. I have 5 more appointments in other departments.

title: UNABLE TO GET THROUGH ON THE PHONE
body:
CANNOT get through on the phone to find out where to send a stool sample, after spending the best (worst) part of an hour listening to the 'hold' music. The information on the website is confusing - ref Belmont Surgery and Nicholstown (neither of which is our local surgery (Adelaide). I just need to know where to take this sample. 
Having said that, once in touch with medical team, no complaints they're brilliant.
PS I would add this isn't a recent 'Covid' related issue, being unable to get through on the phone. I have been on hold for ages in the past, and then gone over in person to the Adelaide to find the receptionists chatting and an empty waiting room. I was told the calls were re- directd from a call centre, but clearly even then, it wasn't working.
The message says that the 'easiest' way to contact the surgery is on the website, using E-consult. This is not always suitable for every question - just a series of irrelevant tick-boxes so you go round in circles.
Please help!!

title: This surgery has gone down hill...
body: This surgery has gone down hill, the attitude of some of their staff is dreadful, everything is an uphill battle and very stressful indeed, they need to remember the main objective of the practice which is to care for people, too much focus on budget cuts to care I feel.

title: Disappointing move of services
body: I have been a patient at this practice for seven-and-a-half years and never had a problem. Today I called to make an appointment for my three-year-old daughter's vaccinations and was told all nurse appointments were now at the Edge Hill site and I was told that all Queens Drive patients were currently going to Edge Lane for pre-booked nurse and GP appointments. I asked was this permanent and were services moving fully to Edge Lane. I was told the receptionist couldn't answer that. I explained that I don't drive and with the current pandemic situation I wouldn't be able to safely get my daughter to the Edge Hill site (it's two busses each way or an hour-long walk) and I was pretty much told that I'd just have to find a way. It was clear that the receptionist felt this was my problem and nothing at all to do with the surgery that had quietly moved essential services three miles away. There was no empathy and no willingness to help. It's obvious that the management haven't considered accessibility for patients in the slightest. I have emailed the surgery with my complaint, especially as patients were assured this sort of thing wouldn't happen when the new owners took over a few years ago. I will be registering my family with another local GP surgery ASAP as I am not willing to drag my children across Liverpool to access services that previously were only a short walk away. I can't imagine that I'll be the only one.

title: Telephones not answered
body:
Each time I have phoned 0300 131 4500 to try and speak to someone on the ward for an update the phone rings for a good 30 minutes or more before the stressed-out switchboard operator finally answers. Then it takes another 30 minutes before the call is answered on the ward - always by medical staff - where are all your ward clerks?  Ward clerks should be answering the calls and either finding someone to help or arranging for a call back at a convenient time.  Fairly simple.

Since visiting is now not allowed, surely you must realise that anxious relatives need to know what is happening and the only way to find anything out is by phoning the hospital.  

I understand that GPs who need to have a patient admitted go through the same performance waiting for switchboard and ending up sending the patient to A&E to be admitted.  The amount of time being WASTED here is beyond belief, medical staff, admin staff and patients time.  Then there is the stress this causes, I don’t think you can measure this.  If you can’t even answer the phone then what else is not being done?  This is in no way a problem for the medical staff to resolve,  it is a system problem for one of your many managers to take responsibility for - not a medically trained person as this would be a complete waste of their skills and time.

Please don’t blame the coronavirus for this as well.

title: Perfect experience
body: Whole environment spotless staff polite and helpful was kept informed of all procedures operation painless and successfully completed in a short time and post op information clear and easily understood 5 star experience

author: Lettrice
title: The phlebotomy team at CUH
body:
My 18 year old daughter is terrified of having blood taken. The team rallied round to reassure; although she was visibly shaking and trying to seek excuses not to have a blood test. Melissa (Mel) in particular gave my daughter reassurance and eventually she allowed her to take blood. The staff were great.  
Thank you

author: amber12347
title: CBT for social anxiety
body:
For a long time, I struggled with social anxiety and depression. I am so happy that I was referred to CBT at Hounslow IAPT with Rashmeet. During the sessions, I learned many strategies and techniques that helped me to improve my self-esteem, confidence, and social skills. Rashmeet was patient and professional. I am really thankful for all her work and positivity.  
I was hesitating to ask for help and didn't know that these services existed. During my first visit, I was so afraid to go... Now I understand the importance of therapy. I learned a lot during the CBT sessions. I learned how social anxiety works, how my old behaviors and thought were making it worse and how should I improve. These skills are life-changing for somebody who had major anxiety while speaking with a friend. Now I am ready to improve my confidence even more and excited to change my life. Thank you Hounslow IAPT and Rashmeet for all your hard work.

author: Clementoni
title: Overnight stay at Antrim Area Hospital
body:
I was taken to hospital by my wife to the emergency department re suspected appendicitis. I was seen very quickly by the triage nurse who sent me through to the observation unit at the back of the emergency department. This was a very busy space and I was put into a bed and a cannula was inserted. I was then left for a number of hours with no one speaking to me or letting me know what has happening. Eventually a Doctor came and examined me and left again. I was told very little, and what little I was told gave me the impression that I was staying in overnight with possible surgery in the morning. This concerned me somewhat. Due to the fact that I was not told anything and that I had no idea what was happening it caused me to become worried. I didn't know whether my wife would have to come and collect me or to bring me an overnight bag. This not only impacted my wife but also our neighbours as we had two young children at home who needed to be cared for should she be required to come to the hospital.  
One nurse, Arlene, spoke to me in a very kind and reassuring manner, she gave me pain killers and explained what I had to do to take them - (suppository), she answered a few questions and it was very nice to have a human touch and a feeling that she actually cared. I appreciate that the department was busy but the lack of communication from anyone was very frustrating. They didn't tell me anything, they didn't speak to me regarding what they thought was wrong with me or if I required surgery what it would be. I also had to have the COVID-19 test and again it felt rushed, impersonal and was not properly explained to me what this would involve. I asked the nurse what was happening with me and possible time frame and she said she would get back to me but never did. This was very frustrating.  
Eventually someone came and spoke to me around 6 hours after I arrived and asked me to go and sit in the corridor as they were moving me at some point to the Emergency Surgery Unit - one of the wards. They said I would be staying overnight - it was at this point I could ring my wife to bring me an overnight bag.  
On arrival to the ward a nurse spoke to me and did some checks but then left me. I wasn't sure whether I was allowed to get in to bed, go to sleep etc but eventually I did anyway as I was so tired. I tried to sleep but it was all but impossible due to the noise.  
My pain medication was renewed and I was told that the consultant would be with me shortly. I was still under the impression that I was going for surgery in the morning but no one had explained any of this to me or what I was being kept in for. Eventually around 8am in the morning a Dr came who spoke to me and then physically examined me. A nurse was there due to the nature of the examination and I have to say that was the first time someone spoke to me and explained what was going on and what they were looking for. The nurse was very reassuring and I very much appreciated her approach. The Doctor advised that I was to go for a cat scan and the result of that would determine whether or not I was to require surgery.  
A nurse came at 11am to take me for my scan and she was lovely, She spoke to me, answered any questions I had and was a very pleasant change. I arrived for my scan and the nurse and Doctor there took time to explain to me what was happening and what they were looking for - they answered any questions I had and addressed any concerns that I had.  
I was then taken back to the ward and eventually a Doctor told me that my scan indicated a slight swelling of the appendix and blocking of the upper colon. That was it. They never said I could go home, or whether I was to stay. They told me I needed no surgery. I was then given something to eat and eventually I had to phone my wife to tell her what I was told. She was a nurse and advised me to speak directly to the consultant and to ask a number of questions re my care, results and reason for staying in the hospital. This eventually happened after a number of my questions were not answered by the staff on the ward.  
I also felt that patient confidentiality was non existent on the ward. The doctors and nurses openly discussed each patient, their history, current medical issues and personal details at the nurses station in full hearing of everyone on the ward. There was one particular female patient who had a number of very personal medical issues that every other patient on the ward could hear - all male.  
Eventually I was advised that they wished to keep me in for observation but I felt that my wife could do that at home and after raising issues advised by my wife I was finally discharged after speaking again with the consultant who at this stage was a little more forthcoming with information.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

links.id: speaking to you as a human and showing you care

author: SecondTimeMum
title: Excellent care in Labour Ward
body:
I was recently taken into labour ward at Aberdeen Maternity Hospital to be induced after my waters had broken with no progress. I wanted to leave a comment to say about the amazing care my husband and myself received while there.  
We had an absolutely amazing midwife called Bethany. She was so kind and friendly which really put my mind at ease about having to give birth haha. It turned out this was her first job post after qualifying as a midwife, I was absolutely shocked as she was so calm, confident and competent in her role. She listened to us, was very encouraging and always went through all my options, particularly surrounding pain relief which meant I never felt too uncomfortable for long. She really just did an excellent job in all departments and we want her to know what an amazing difference she made to our experience. I'm a nurse myself and definitely wasn't this good in my first job! Please let her know how great she is!  
Everyone else we came into contact with was lovely also from the charge midwife, student midwives to doctors and anaesthetists. They all made giving birth during a pandemic easier than I was anticipating.  
Just wanted to thank you all for the great job you do and thanks for helping us bring our son into the world in a lovely, calm and professional way!

author: Biker Nicky
title: Broken radious
body:
Following a fall on my bike on the Quantock Hills, I broke my radious bone and cut my knee. I was a little shocked, new to the area (had only been living here for three days and didn't even know where the A&E was located. I didn't know what to expect from 'The Musgrove Hospital'.  
The A&E staff were brilliant. They managed to reset the bone, stitch the knee, all with very little memorable pain.  
Waiting times were minimal compared to my previous London hospital experiences. Follow up treatment & letters were exceptional.

author: Gemmacgls
title: Ridiculous’
body:
I waiting 8 months to have an appointment with the personality disorder team, a week before my appointment I called them as I hadn’t heard anything within the 8 months only to find out I had been discharged!  
I hadn’t even seen or spoken to anyone within this time and probably wouldn’t have been told if I hadn’t of called. It is unacceptable.

author: positivethinking84
title: Miscarriage care
body:
I attended the early pregnancy unit in causeway hospital for a scan at seven weeks following a scare. The nurse Nicola scanned me and everything was fine. We could see a heartbeat. I was so relieved. I was advised to attend again for a further scan in a couple of weeks.  
Fast forward two weeks. I had been so sick so not thinking anything was wrong, I skipped back into the early pregnancy unit to see my baby again. I was so excited! I hopped on to the couch and could see my wee baby on the scanner. Shauna the nurse started to look and look. She kept trying different angles but neither of us could see that wee flicker of my baby's heartbeat. Shauna called for the doctor. Dr white proceeded to scan me again. In my head I was desperately hoping we had just missed it. But then I just remember Dr White's words... "I'm so sorry." I just cried. I couldn't believe it! The baby measured perfectly but no heartbeat. Shock set in. Shauna was so reassuring and compassionate. My options were given to me and I was advised to call back the following day to arrange what to do next. The end of the week came and I was taken in for surgical management. Nurses Terri and Marian were so attentive. They kept me regularly informed about getting to theatre. The three student nurses were lovely. Caitlin, Carla and Chloe from Ulster University and Queens. It was great to see them teaching and supporting each other's learning. They kept asking me if I needed anything and popping in to check if I was okay. Dr Yazmin explained the procedure to me. I was obviously upset but she was very caring.The end of the day came. Theatres had been so busy that day that I had to return the following day for my procedure.I attended the next day as planned. I was seen by Dr Shafalika and the anaesthetist Dr Maha fairly promptly. I was advised that my procedure would be done under spinal which I was quite nervous about but again, they reassured me.I was wheeled to theatre by a nurse called Margaret and Dr Yazmin. In the anaesthetic room, I was met by a nurse called Natalie. I was so nervous and obviously upset but she was so reassuring. Into theatre I go to be met by Dr Shafalika, Dr Maha and a team of nurses. I just remember crying. Pure devastation set in. But a nurse called Helen said the kindest words to me that I will never forget. Her compassion and care was amazing. She made me feel like I wasn't alone, even though it is the most lonely of experiences. Following my spinal, Nurse Natalie stood by my side the whole time. Reassuring me constantly. The masks and visors didn't make a difference because I could see their smiles and kindness by their eyes. Once the procedure was completed, I went to recovery to be met by a lovely nurse called Esther. Again, Esther fully reassured me and made me laugh even. Natalie and Helen also came to see how I was doing. These three nurses provided me with such comfort and support.Helen and Esther wheeled me back to the ward, where Nurses Orla and Margaret proceeded to provide me with great care and such kindness. Mandy the HCA brought me tea and toast and chatted away to me. I was so thankful for her company and cheerfulness. I guess I am writing this to help me come to terms with all that has happened. Despite my misfortune I wanted to acknowledge the staff that cared for me. From my trauma, I have experienced the true kindness, compassion, empathy and great care from a whole team of doctors and nursing staff. Even during such difficult times, they are still providing a service which is invaluable to women experiencing this heart ache. I hope that they get to see this and that they know how truly thankful I am for their comfort and support at such a difficult time.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Kelsmac
title: Antenatal care
body: It has been disjointed and extremely poorly organised. Also as the patient I am made to feel like I am to blame for all of it. I see 3 medical professionals as part of my antenatal care and not one of them knows what the other is doing. They speak to me like I’m a child and expect me to answer their questions regards the basis of the decisions being made about my care, I’m not a doctor or midwife so I’m unsure how to answer. After this experience I’ll never go through pregnancy on NHS care, it’s at the very best adequate as in I have enough faith that myself and my child will survive with minimal trauma but not a lot beyond this.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: nffc
title: Alcohol Detox
body:
I'm 34 years old. I have enjoyed having a drink since being a teenager. I have always been a pretty anxious person and I would often have a couple of drinks to calm my nerves if i had plans for that day.  
As I got into my late 20s I realised I was drinking daily. Over the last four years or so it just escalated and gradually got worse over time. I found myself going from medium strength beer, to stronger strength cans and then mainly onto spirits. Around three years ago I realised I was dependent. I was needing drink just to sleep or to have an appetite. I felt moody if I hadn't had a drink and it was affecting my relationship and home life in general. Up until the week I started my detox I would be on 20+ units per day, I couldn't sleep for more than a couple of hours without waking up sweating, shaking, wretching and needing more drink just to not feel ill.  
I contacted CGL as I was now desperate and I had an assessment over the phone with a lady called Carol. She then put me in contact me a man named Stuart. I explained my situation and how I really thought I need a detox to break the drinking cycle. He was great with me and told me he would send the report to my doctor and get back to me.  
I was successful in getting a detox and the relief of that alone was massive. I knew I now had a chance to sort my life out.  
I met with John three days before my detox started. He dropped off equipment and went through what to expect and that was really helpful and reassuring.  
The detox started on the Monday morning. I was pretty much out of it the first day, nodding quite alot but I felt OK and relaxed and it was going better than I had expected. John checked on me in person and we had a decent chat. Stuart was on the phone twice a day, checking on me, taking my blood pressure and temperature readings. From day two onwards I continued to take my medication and I felt fine! I couldn't believe how manageable the detox was. I was expecting a struggle and it was the opposite. I kept waiting for a bad day to happen but it never did. I was never once feeling bad.  
I have now completed my detox and I feel like a new man. I am happier, I feel so much healthier, I am sleeping and eating. The shakes have gone. I am finally rid of the alcohol and I have never felt better.  
A big thing I want to mention is the fact it was a home detox. With me being anxious, I would have felt so much more nervous and worried if I didn't have the chance to do it in my own home. It made it so much easier for me. Home detox should always be an option in future for people in a similar situation.  
I want to say a massive thanks from top to bottom to everybody at CGL for helping me get rid of my addiction. Two people I really want to single out are Stuart and John.  
Stuart was great on the phone, very calming and full of knowledge. I would ask a question and he would always be very informative and always have time to speak for as long as I needed.  
John was great and from the minute I met him I knew this guy was going to be a big help to me, and he was. He was very open and honest about his past and everything he was saying I could relate to in some way. Having somebody who was once in the position I was facing and who had overcome the same problems was a massive plus for me. John is very passionate and I can tell this is more than just a job to him and I've taken alot of things on board from what he has been drilling into me. John has offered to continue supporting me should I need it which is reassuring.  
Thanks for literally saving my life.

author: empathykr36
title: Prompt care for stroke
body:
Tingling feeling on right side of jaw in late June but no action taken. The following day tingling had also affected right hand, lower jaw on right side which made me contact GP the following day.  
Due to lockdown appointment was by telephone. My GP arranged for me to be examined by Crosshouse Hospital Assessment Unit.  
After several test I was moved to ward 3d and kept in overnight, with other tests being carried out throughout my stay.  
The attention given by nursing staff and other sections was superb, as were the doctors. Catering, porters, cleaners - all great.

author: heronbb93
title: First class service at assessment hub
body:
Appointment arranged with the hub by my GP, within 4 hours of my GP appointment. The speed of the provision of the service was excellent and the service provided was first class.  
The consultation was with a specialist nurse and she very skilfully assessed my condition and in consultation with a consultant provided me with a treatment plan, with further test arranged. She subsequently provided me with advice by telephone, at my request, and she was able to put my mind at rest about medication etc.  
Overall, a very professional service, suited to my particular needs.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Eve68
title: Injury to ribs
body:
Attended Lagan Valley ED last week following a fall at home. Everyone I came in contact with without exception were both kind and also very professional.  
I was triaged quickly , sent for X-ray and treated appropriately. At all times full explanation was given and all questions answered.  
Excellent service and very fortunate to be treated so well. As a health care professional myself I know good care when I see it and LVH go above and beyond .

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: phoenixwe77
title: Could not praise the staff enough
body: Met at doorway and given mask etc. Asked to wash hands then brought into the ward for my medication. Staff was excellent in reassuring my safety and well being. Everything was explained as to what would happen. I felt safe at all times, staff kept checking on my well being throughout my time. Could not praise the staff enough. Thank you

body:
Unable to fault my visit today. So much kindness especially the nurse who assessed me at first and the two girls who did my chest xray.  
So good to have all the tests in one morning and to get the results of them too.  
Thank you so much cardiac assess hub.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: summer2112
title: Lack of appropriate care
body:
Over three years ago I underwent the ICSA Child sex abuse enquiry about a serious sexual assault. I was told that I needed appropriate care and to be assessed for PTSD for rape. I came back and went to my GP as this was the gateway to the care I needed. Months later still nothing. I complained that nothing had been done to the board and was promptly seen by a psychiatrist who told me that as a charity that specialised in rape counselling had been involved and had offered me care if I hadn’t received any from the trust That I should stick with that. I told them that I couldn’t access this for months and still nothing was offered.  
I got very ill and had new symptoms of hallucinations and blackouts so back to the go. The early intervention team saw me quickly And assessed me deciding I wasn’t psychotic but undergoing extreme distress and stress. I agreed with this. I received a care coordinator and only recently a junior psychologist obviously only by telephone due to covid. No assessment for PTSD even though this was what I’ve requested throughout. Still have blackouts still have hallucinations and no assessment no specialist treatment. I’m sick of begging for the care I need.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys NHS Foundation Trust

author: apriley96
title: Wonderful people at Inclusion
body:
Inclusion Basingstoke was amazing. I met loads of friendly people there. I loved being there with the staff and other clients. They couldn't get rid of me, I virtually lived there for six months. We laughed, we cried, we chatted, and we learned.  
When I arrived, I hardly knew what day it was, or what I was doing but that as all changed now. I am peaceful and I have hope for the future. I am comfortable with my thoughts, and my mind is sharp again. In one month's time I will have been alcohol free for one year. Life is so much better now and its all thanks to the wonderful people at Incusion! :)xxx

author: novembernz49
title: Helpful staff
body:
The day staff are fantastic, they are so caring and attentive.  
I live right beside Craigavan hospital but it didn't really bother me coming to South Tyrone as all the same staff were here so made me feel so much more comfortable.  
Very spread out - felt safe.  
My husband couldn't be here so I was anxious coming on my own - staff very helpful and felt ok hearing familiar voices.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: guidett99
title: Talking honestly without judgement
body:
I was very nervous to join a group but was made to feel comfortable - Inclusion created a safe space to talk honestly without judgement. The meetings have also provided me with routine and the support has been completely reliable. I felt a small sense of community within my town. I have been constantly impressed with, and hugely grateful for the level of commitment by my key worker, even though as addicts we often can't return the favour. I always feel listened too and respected.  
I have and continue to learn from their services and I am so grateful for the support I have received over the past few years.

author: betaec63
title: Thank you to the staff of the Seamoor Unit
body:
Words are not enough to express our sincere thanks to you all! Your care, attention and treatment throughout our troubles has been truly wonderful.  
You are all fantastic people. We feel so blessed to have you there in our time of need. We both thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: defenderpt99
title: Spoken to as a human being
body:
Probably the best service I have ever used. From self referral to discharge had more to offer than any other services.  
Groups, meditation, reflexology, acupuncture + more!  
The thing that counted most was being spoken to as a human being with honesty and respect. Not looked down on.  
My key worker helped me more than she will ever know. As a service user I would highly recommend this service.

author: Emmrd63
title: Grateful for help
body: Thank you for taking the time to not just listen to me but to hear me. I’m so grateful for your help and the information you provided. I am more than capable of dealing with these issues myself, but I’m very aware that as a patient, I will not be listened to at my meeting, but I know that if you are there, they will have to listen to what I have to say, and actually do something

author: Lou Lee
title: My care at Peggy Wood breast care centre today
body:
I was referred to the Peggy Wood breast care centre by my consultant because 8 years after treatment for DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) I was still finding issues. This time physical changes to the treated breast.  
I was early but staff swiftly made me feel comfortable and tried to help. The clinic was busy but despite the fact I should have been in the clinic later in the day I was reassured and quickly dealt with. My mammogram was quick and despite thinking I would need to wait some time I was quickly placed for a further ultrasound scan.  
The nurses were so lovely. Sensitive and emotionally intelligent. I was joined by the doctor on duty - in fact the doctor that had told me I had DCIS 8 years earlier. She talked me through the scan and the reasons for the changes I was experiencing. I felt absolutely confident in her authoritative, calm and reassuring approach. The outcome for me was positive and I can only praise the staff involved. Thank you to all of them.  
I would say however, I had surgery followed by radiotherapy at Maidstone 8 years ago. The treatment and staff were outstanding throughout. But, at the end of the radiotherapy I had a final meeting with someone to send me on my way. Unfortunately, they were male and I could barely understand their diction as English was not their mother tongue. It would have made so much difference to me in the years that have followed to have been talked through the changes I might expect and what should concern me to seek further help.  
I remain in the care of this Maidstone/ TWells team and am eternally grateful for it. I really do appreciate the lengths they go to!

title: Great understanding and listening skills
body:
Over the last few weeks I needed advice and support and that is what I got! 
Understanding is priceless. 
Thank you

author: coordinationzg73
title: Amazing staff and service
body:
I had to be brought to hospital to the chest pain hub and get assessed.  
My heart was racing very fast and I was met by two lovely, professional and very knowledgeable nurses.  
Staff nurses Michelle & Janet went above and beyond to help me. They settled my nerves and got me the correct treatment and assessment carried out. Amazing staff and service.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Fiona 1984
title: Inducing
body:
I was induced when I was 41 weeks +2 days the staff looked after me on maternity ward wasn’t bad. After 2 days of inducing I was taken on delivery suite-midwifes were not bad, gave me all the information I need.  
After 14hrs of labour I was asked to push which I couldn’t manage without help. I had forceps delivery. The midwife pass me the baby - 3 times I wiped blood that was coming out from his mouth. I asked them if that is normal but no one answered. After 45 min my son collapsed. He was resuscitated and send in Bolton for cooling treatment.  
I’m so grateful for Bolton NICU staff as they were brilliant - they saved our son and they gave us as a new parents very good support. After 6 days they have to send us back in Blackpool to finish the course of antibiotics which my son had. The staff of NICU left me alone (new mum) in the room for all night baby was crying all night no one even came in our room to check if we are ok. They left me antibiotics for the little one one the table and told me to give him when I will feed him. That was shocking.  
After 2 days the doctor came and told me we can be discharged to go home. I asked what was the level of the infection for my baby as they told me have to be below 10 in Blackpool and below 5 in Bolton! Don’t know why is so big difference! ! ! Doctor couldn’t answer my question as they didn’t know and was happy to discharge us home. I think is absolutely shocking how the nurses and doctors didn’t show us care. After this experience I will never have a more babies and I speak with all my pregnant friends to not have the babies in Victoria as my care was really poor. To be honest I don’t think if we will stay in the Vic after what happened my son will be how he is today - I know Bolton NICU did everything they could to safe him and they did. They really care which I can’t say about Blackpool staff. Really disappointed

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Unreasonable and ill mannered
body:
I requested a repeat prescription and since they refuse to give me more than 4 weeks’ supply, I asked for 2 months’ supply as I’m going on holiday for 3 weeks in one month’s time. 

My request was ignored and I was given only 1 month without any explanation. So arrogant that the courtesy of a response is not deemed necessary. Is it really necessary to be so discourteous?

I queried it and was told I should request the next issue while on holiday. 
They literally expected me to find internet access in a remote camping location in order to request the next prescription and then somehow identify and find transport ( I cannot drive due to seizures) to a pharmacy in the nearest town.

This is objectively unreasonable. Who needs this kind of stress and inconvenience while on holiday? 

Eventually they relented and I was begrudgingly given a 2 month supply. Ironically the same GP previously refused to prescribe medication for chronic and debilitating migraines (which would only have been needed on an ad hoc basis) and was then instructed by the consultant to issue this controlled drug instead which needs to be taken daily for life.

title: Excellent department
body: I would like to say a massive thank you to the team of staff that treated me in the hysteroscopy clinic on Monday  . The care and support I received before during and after my procedure was out standing , I would truly rate my visit 100% and the consultant and nurses a real credit to addenbrooks .

readBy.name: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Disappointed Bunny
title: Trouble getting through on the phone
body:
I routinely have difficulty contacting the Stonebridge Centre in Nottingham. If I ring within the opening hours, but at the wrong time of day, and the doctor's secretary has finished for the day, there is apparently, no way to leave a message. I think this may be a centralised switchboard that routes calls to different centres and this seems to exacerbate the issue.  
My recent attempts to just reorder a prescription have been thwarted and as I write this, I have been listening to "on hold" music for just over 20 minutes.  
I accept that many publicly funded services are overstretched but surely the ability to make contact is a basic requirement of offering a service. The lack of an email contact address seems to be an implausible oversight in the 21st century and makes it appear that the service wishes to place barriers in place of its clients.  
Based on the number of times that this has happened, I doubt that it is just me experiencing this and I would appreciate it if someone could address this issue.

author: Frustrated by lack of care and professionalism
title: Lack of care and professionalism
body: My partner was transferred here from another ward. Reason given was “concerned about social well-being”. Therefore, moved into a “stroke and elderly care ward”. He had NOT had a stroke neither did he require elderly care. He has diabetes type 1. Since moving to this ward he has not managed to eat food resulting in “hypos”. He developed large swelling in his abdomen where the nurses continually injected into same area. Our family had to demand that he be taken for a shower after 7 days of lack of care. He was left without clothing ie. no underwear and exposed to anyone walking by. Several members of staff did not wear masks. AND still don’t. Observed after 7 visits! When my partner needed to use the toilet he had to borrow a crutch from a patient in the same ward as none were available for his sole use. No doctors ever available for us to consult with and phone constantly engaged when trying to organise visits. With the exception of one nurse, we all found the staff to be very uncaring and extremely unhelpful. These people give the profession a very bad name.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: corridoryp47
title: Wonderful care
body:
As I awoke at approx 7.00 am 12/07/20 I felt unwell, ie having difficulty in pronouncing my words. My wife phone for the ambulance which arrived in a matter of minutes. The paramedics were just wonderful. they immediately carried out medical checks and in a matter of minutes I was on my way to hospital QMC North.  
On arrival at the hospital I again received wonderful care and attention from the hospital medics. After the initial assessment I was promptly on my for a brain scan. the diagnosis was that i had suffered a minor stroke. I spent one night in hospital and discharged the next day approx. 4.00 pm. I was prescribed medication which will be continued via my GP.  
On 12th August 2020 I will have a tape recorder attached for 24 hours to monitor my heartbeat.  
There is nothing I could fault regarding the care and service that i received from all the medical professionals that cared for me.  
Many many thanks go to you all.

author: hydrazn63
title: Hip Replacement
body:
My operation was considerably delayed by Covid and I was fortunate to be operated on on 13th July 2020 soon after Ward 10 in Kirkcaldy Victoria reopened. However, following my hip operation I must thank all the staff for all their commitment, care and professionalism. I couldn't have been in better hands.  
My hip had deteriorated severely over the past year and the last few months have been a tremendous trial bearing constant pain while in Covid 19 lockdown  
It was obvious not only what a lot of work has been done both in terms of physical change at the hospital but also in the huge training load in response to Covid to allow my and the elective surgery of many others to restart. I am deeply grateful that the staff put themselves in harm's way from Covid to help others. Covid arrangements also seem to require some dispersal of staff leading to increased hours of work. They are working a 6 day week to help clear the backlog of cases.  
Particular mention needs to be made of individuals in the staff in and around Ward 10. Andy, Consutant Orthopaedic Surgeon, Chris, Anaesthetist, Charge Nurse Lorna, Nurses Karen, Dorma, John, Beth, Lorraine, Emma, Kath, Susan, and Susan, Nicky (Preop), Keeva (Physio),and Moira (Occupational Therapy). Apologies to anyone I've missed.  
I was also delighted that the bit of bone they removed can be of use to others via the Blood Transfusion Service.  
Pain levels in the operated leg have already been dramatically reduced and the exercises pre and post op are being so beneficial that I am already out walking short distances in the open air.  
My other hip has now also significantly deteriorated and I hope to be back soon to have it done. I'm not looking forward to it as for any operation, but the care professionalism and good humour of the staff make it so much more bearable.

author: Ruperta
title: Wishaw University Hospital
body: I just wanted to thank all the staff of Ward 5 University Hospital Wishaw for their excellent standard of care during my recent stay in hospital. Staff across all disciplines, medical, nursing, ancillary, IBD nurses etc treated me with professionalism, respect, compassion and always with a smile. Can't thank them enough for helping me get back onto the road to health, I will be forever grateful. Great team effort, thank you so much. Stay safe

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: gifthk77
title: Arden ward
body: I came in to the Arden ward near the end of May, the treatment has been really good. I have bipolar and the ward has improved 100% since I was last here in 2006. We have a room of our own and shower next door. The staff are of a much higher standard. They really do care and have to deal with some quite difficult to manage patients, even after receiving abuse they forgive and move on. Maybe a new pool table and a Jacuzzi could be added. Then I would stay forever.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: LGP
title: Not listened to on referral phonecall
body: I contacted mid notts crisis team in order to make a referral to them regarding somebody that I know. Throughout the call I felt as though the staff member wasn't listening to me and in fact asked me questions that I had already answered on more than one occasion. I was calling in the context of a professional and I came away from the call feeling angry and patronised. I hope that service users can feel more listened to and supported than I did.

title: Receptionist
body: My wife had an appointment for her b12 injection today but was refused as the receptionist told her she was late for her appointment! The appointment was booked for 12am but the receptionist argued it was 11.50 and she was 8 minutes late! I was with my wife when she booked the appointment! The time it was booked for was 12am ! Disgusting attitude by the receptionist and my wife has waited a long time for this injection! Shameful service!

author: aprilhc36
title: Better than my GP
body: Seen by quickly and more efficiently than my own GP.   Nurse Michelle was good at explaining and very helpful.   She was better than my gp - a very good service

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jenny123
title: District Nurse Visit Overnight
body:
My granda has recently taken a turn for the worse and is now bed ridden and end of life care. Last night he was choking and making strange noises with his breathing. Called NHS24 who sent out two nurses.  
One of the nurses was lovely and I couldn’t fault her. However the other nurse seemed to have an attitude. I felt they were rude and very dismissive of anything we were saying. I get it was the early hours of the morning but that is your job. She seemed to have left the care and compassion at the front door when she came in! When someone is dying it its traumatic for the person and the family and the last thing anyone needs in this situation is an attitude from someone who is supposed to be helping. Puts me off calling for help in the future.

readBy.name: University of Glasgow - School of Medicine, Dentistry and Nursing

author: corvuspk67
title: I felt comforted
body:
I felt safe on Orion :)  
I was poorly with corona virus but I was looked after with oxygen in my own room.  
People comforted me when I got upset  
They clean the unit every day  
Sometimes I had sandwiches too much because i didn't like the meals. They don't change the menu much.  
I liked the puddings  
I liked playing boccia and lots of games like dominoes, cards and frustration.  
I most enjoyed coffee mornings with tea and biscuits.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Oldershaw
title: Her explanation of what was to happen and her delivery of the procedure was excellent.
body: Attended this unit this morning for a procedure and firstly can I say there aren’t enough superlatives in the Oxford English Dictionary to apply to all NHS staff for the excellent service they provide but I will try. The work of Kirsty and her support from Claire was up to the highest standard we all have experienced. To single out Kirsty her explanation of what was to happen and her delivery of the procedure was excellent. If you attend this unit be assured your experience will be second to none.

CURED

title: The worst doctors I have ever been too
body: You get told different things by different people depending on who you speak too doesn’t seem to be any communication between the staff and doctors ,your made to feel as if you are a problem ,the receptionists are more or less all patronising and do little to help you  prescriptions that should take 2 working days sometimes take weeks

author: Miss Serendipity
title: Unplanned admission for Appendectomy - Royal Infirmary, Edinburgh
body:
On Saturday 1st August 2020, I presented to the GP Out of Hours service at St John's Hospital, Livingston. After undergoing an initial assessment, I was transferred to the Surgical Assessment Unit at the Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh for further tests.  
Soon after arrival at the Royal, a CT-scan quickly identified the problem - an episode of appendicitis. By midnight I was whizzed into the operating theatre and keyhole surgery removed the offending piece of my anatomy!  
I want to use Care Opinion to share my sincere thanks for the professionalism, attention, care and compassion I experienced during my journey. The nurses, doctors and HCSWs involved in my treatment managed to balance their professionalism with genuine care - and a sense of humour! Despite feeling ++ vulnerable, the whole procedure was made so much more bearable by their approach. Thank you nursing staff on duty at St John's OOO service and the Multi-Disciplinary Team who managed my care at The Royal Infirmary. I only wish I had your names to include in this feedback!  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']  
[Very happy with 'Staff skills']  
[Very happy with 'Explanations']  
[Very happy with 'Doctor']  
[Very happy with 'Nurses']  
[Very happy with 'Being given time']

author: echodr33

body: Always feel welcome and comfortable.   Well looked after.   Absolutely lovely staff.
